Habitat Complexity: high in semi-natural outdoor field enclosures with heterogeneous vegetation and variable terrain, positively associated with time since burning, discussed as an ecological factor influencing territory size/defense (no Microtus ochrogaster-specific data)
Terrain ruggedness and north-south aspect predict Microtus pennsylvanicus–associated assemblages; land-cover types are less predictive.

Territoriality (males): Variable territory size: small to large
Habitat Complexity: low (maize crop fields near villages), swale (preferred habitat), high complexity in bushland (H'=0.98; 19 Mus musculus individuals)

Social Dominance Hierarchy: Non-linear (dominance hierarchy observed; linearity not specified)
Habitat Complexity: Heterogeneous, edge-rich habitats across urban and natural landscapes (e.g., sewers, ground level of buildings, landfills)

Social Dominance Hierarchy: Linear (typical) with a single breeding female dominant and non-breeders subordinate; some studies report non-linear structures.
Group Size During Reproduction: 2–100 individuals (encompassing small to medium groups; reported ranges 2–41 and 10–100)
Habitat Complexity: High-complexity underground burrow systems (maze with multiple chambers and tunnels), including wild natural and captive artificial burrows

Social Dominance Hierarchy: Non-linear, Linear; alpha-based hierarchy (Subject1 dominant male; Subject2 later alpha)
Migratory behavior: not migratory biologically, migratory under CMS legal definition
Habitat Complexity: Enclosure features (vertical space, multilevel sleeping sites, climbing structures); forest-mosaic/large outdoor naturalistic enclosures with diverse features (waterfall, trees, cliffs, termite mounds, slack lines) and indoor off-display areas.

Migratory behavior: 24% of isolated human Caco-2 cells exhibited migratory behavior at the start of live imaging.
Habitat Complexity: Heterogeneous habitat structure with variable connectivity (forest-to-savanna transitions) and diverse within-human microhabitats (clinical sites: blood, endotracheal secretions, tracheal exudate, sputum, wounds).
